_exec_summary.SummaryText:
About 3 times a year Midwest PMS hires a company to come in and react to make 10-34-0.   We only order the rail cars, we never touch them, they are on our premises for about 4 days full.  When Mears gets done we release the car amd the railroad will pick it up at their convience.  We do not own the 10-34-0 until it is used so it is really there on consignment.

Our employees are trained in ammonia, know what to do in case of an emergency but Mears usually shows up about 7:00 pm and is gone before 8:00 am the next morning.  Thus we have no employee exposure to any type of disaster as the plant is closed.

Our county emergency coordinator (Sherri Blaha) is notified when the car comes into Minatare.  She notifies the Minatare Fire Chief, and the Scottsbluff Hazmat team which has an agreement on any hazardous material spill  or leak with Minatare Fire Dept and they are ready as soon as that car is spotted by Burlington Northern Railroad.   The City of Scottsbluff is 8 miles from the city of Minatare.

The Facility Policy
Midwest PMS owners, managemet and employees are committed to the prevention of any accidential releases of ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with The Mears Co, Local Fire Dept and Haz Mat Team from Scottsbluff to minimumize the impact of the release to the people and the environment.

Facility Information.
The primary activity of Midwest PMS is to stand back and Let Mears do their job.

The maximum storage that Mears would have there is 150,000 pounds (1 rail car)

The worst Case Scenario would be the release of 150,000 pounds and the distance to the endpoint would be .41 mile

The alternative release scenario would be the breaking of a hose, the automatic shut off valve would engage as well as the operator shutting it off manually and the end point of disperion will be .41 miles

Prevention Plan
Midwest PMS has implemented the provcision of Safety Requirements for the Storage and handling of Ammonia K-61.

1, published by the American National Standars Institure Inc. and the standards of the US OSHA 29 CFR 1919.111 Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.   All of this would be the responsibility of The Mears Co. the Reactor of the Ammonia

Firve Year Accident History           None

Midwest PMS has a emergency response action plan 29 CFR 1910.38

Provided State and local authorities the emergency planning and community right to know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA)

A written emergency response program, in accordance w/ OSHA standare 29 CFR 1910.120 including pre-emergency planning and employee training. 

Safety improvement is an on-going process of Midwest PMS
